dt: {bc}the act or manner or an instance of {d_link|treating|treat:1} someone or something: such as

dt.t: The actor requires careful {wi}treatment{/wi}.

… he always treated people with whom he disagreed with utmost civility and never allowed his scholarly predispositions to interfere with respectful {wi}treatment{/wi} of students holding differing views.

dt: {bc}the action or manner of dealing with something (such as a topic) often in a specified way

dt.t: … the best and most comprehensive {wi}treatment{/wi} of American foreign oil policy that has so far been written.
… cinematic {wi}treatments{/wi} of organized crime as GoodFellas, Godfather III and Miller's Crossing.

… most of us readers assume that this conflict of interest is the reason PC Magazine reviews of Microsoft products are softball {wi}treatments{/wi} that in no way reflect the actual experiences of users, who are plagued with constant program crashes.

dt: {bc}the action or way of treating a patient or a condition medically or surgically {bc}management and care to prevent, cure, ameliorate, or slow progression of a medical condition

dt.t: {wi}treatment{/wi} of accident victims
palliative {wi}treatment{/wi} of inoperable cancer
{wi}treatment{/wi} of a blocked artery
infertility{wi} treatments{/wi}
{wi}treatment{/wi} of diabetic patients

dt: {bc}an instance of treating a patient or medical condition

dt.t: patients requiring numerous chemotherapy {wi}treatments{/wi}
Removal of the skin growth required a single{wi} treatment{/wi}.

dt: {bc}subjection of something to the action of an agent or process

dt.t: sewage {wi}treatment{/wi}
It is the most economical and practical method of purification and {wi}treatmen{/wi}t of water.
a wastewater {wi}treatment{/wi} plant

dt: {bc}a therapeutic agent, therapy, or procedure used to treat a medical condition

dt.t: Placebos—medical {wi}treatments{/wi} that contain no active ingredients—have triggered an outbreak of controversy …

dt: {bc}something (such as a product or technique) used in treating, enhancing, or improving the performance, condition, or appearance of someone or something

dt.t: exfoliating skin {wi}treatments{/wi}
He cares about the condition of hair, invents {wi}treatments{/wi} as well as styles, and has brought out a special hair-care product made of bone marrow.
Regularly apply a waterproofing {wi}treatment{/wi} suitable for the boot whether it be normal leather, nubuck or suede.

Wainscoting is paneling that lines the lower part of the walls in a room. This decorative {wi}treatment{/wi} usually goes as high as chair rail height, but can be raised higher for a more elegant wall {wi}treatment{/wi}.

dt: {bc}the techniques or actions customarily applied in a specified situation: such as
{bc}the provision (such as by a store or restaurant) of the goods or services associated with a visit, fee, or order

dt.t: The party received special{wi} treatment{/wi} at the restaurant.

{ldquo}If you want luxury goods, then walking into a Gucci or Prada or Cartier and getting {phrase}the full treatment{/phrase} and sitting on the cushy leather banquette is part of the experience,{rdquo} says freelance writer and fashion aficionada Lisbeth Levine.

dt: {bc}a pattern of actions (such as the bestowal of gifts and favors) designed to reward, encourage, or convince

dt.t: … he has been getting the standard {wi}treatment{/wi} of cocktail parties, press interviews and deals with advertisers …

In those early days, [Gerald] Ford was invited to the White House by the natty, peppery Harry Truman, who wanted $5 million to renovate the crumbling building. Ford got {phrase}the full treatment{/phrase}, with amateur architect Truman pointing out sagging floors and the lack of closets. Truman got his money.

dt: {bc}a pattern of actions (such as insults or physical punishment) designed to punish or persuade
used especially in phrases like {it}get the treatment{/it} and {it}give (someone) the treatment{/it}

dt.t: When asked what MI [Military Intelligence] said, he [Sergeant Javal S. Davis] stated: {ldquo}Loosen this guy up for us. Make sure he has a bad night. Make sure he gets the {wi}treatment{/wi}.{rdquo}
Some of the cops at the station house were ready to take him into a back room and give him {ldquo}the {wi}treatment{/wi}{rdquo} for passing himself off as one of them.
Instead, the press corps closed their minds and treated dissenters like pariahs to coerce conformity. NBC News got the full {wi}treatment{/wi} when it dared to break ranks.

shortdef: the act or manner or an instance of treating someone or something: such as
the action or manner of dealing with something (such as a topic) often in a specified way

dt: {bc}to treat (a material, such as metal) by heating and cooling in a way that will produce desired properties

shortdef: to subject to heat; especially : to treat (a material, such as metal) by heating and cooling in a way that will produce desired properties
to treat cruelly or improperly : maltreat

dt: {bc}an act or instance of {d_link|treating|treat:1} someone or something in advance {bc}preliminary or preparatory treatment

dt.t: {wi}pretreatment{/wi} of stains
{wi}pretreatment{/wi} of a surface for painting
… {wi}pretreatment{/wi} is often required to remove oil and grease from the waste water.
… will allow public works crews to apply salt brine to pre-treat city streets before snow events. The {wi}pre-treatment{/wi} creates an additional layer that helps to melt snow …
A drug called atropine can reverse the effects if administered promptly, and {wi}pretreatment{/wi} with pyridostigmine can help shield the body …
Oils give great shine, but I also use them as a {wi}pretreatment{/wi} to prevent damage prior to coloring my natural hair.

shortdef: an act or instance of treating someone or something in advance : preliminary or preparatory treatment; also : a substance used for such treatment

dt: {bc}the act or an instance of medicating oneself or {d_link|treating|treat:1} one's own disease without medical supervision or intervention

dt.t: Unlike other foot problems, bunions are not amenable to {wi}self-treatment{/wi}.
Some attempt risky {wi}self-treatments{/wi}, such as bathing in kerosene or bleach …

shortdef: the act or an instance of medicating oneself or treating one's own disease without medical supervision or intervention

dt: {bc}an act of completely ignoring a person or thing by resort to silence especially as a means of expressing contempt or disapproval

shortdef: an act of completely ignoring a person or thing by resort to silence especially as a means of expressing contempt or disapproval

dt: {bc}a decorative covering (such as a curtain, shade, or valance) for a window or part of a window

dt.t: Much of the fabric and other decorative materials for {wi}window treatments{/wi}, as the curtains are called, were donated by manufacturers.
{ldquo}{wi}Window treatments{/wi}, such as shades and drapes, are little luxuries that make mornings more serene. … ,{rdquo} [Alessandra] Woods says.

shortdef: a decorative covering (such as a curtain, shade, or valance) for a window or part of a window
